A thematic third move in the Open Sicilian: White makes his move in the centre.

This move initiates the Sicilian Najdorf Variation, a variation on the Sicilian with seemingly endless possibilities. Black's idea behind this innocuous-looking pawn move is to start off a queenside expansion to gain space.

This move initiates the Sicilian Najdorf Variation, a variation on the Sicilian with seemingly endless possibilities. Black's idea behind this innocuous-looking pawn move is to start off a queenside expansion to gain space.

And this move begins the ultra-sharp Poisoned Pawn variation of the Sicilian Najdorf. This is a bold sortie by the Black queen to grab a pawn deep in White's position; the pawn is "poisoned" because Black's queen may not get out alive. Fischer always believed that any tempi wasted by Black extricating his queen were outweighed by the pawn advantage.

This move is and was completely unexpected, and stunned spectators and analysers and trainers on both sides. White's knight retreats to its original square!

After White's surprising knight move, Fischer became suspicious and played several inaccurate moves, which are fatal in such a sharp opening. I would love to identify these "inaccurate moves" for you, but I do not know which they are! Can anyone help?

Why that queen doesn't just escape to d8 is beyond me. Of course White would take the knight on d6, but Black can capture the bishop on g4. I think 22...Qb5 would have saved the game, at least temporarily, for Black! Does anyone else think so?

By then, as Fischer was spending ages on his move, Spassky had gone and was pacing up and down the corridors. By the time he got back, Fischer had decided to resign, and had left the hall.

In case you would like to know, Fischer eventually won the match overall, becoming the new world champion for chess.

Extra descriptions e.g. how the spectators were stunned after Spassky's 14th move, how Spassky was pacing the corridors etc. were all discovered from Daniel Johnson's book "White King and Red Queen" though most analysis of the moves themselves did not come from here.
